script.message: Hi there!
Let's query for Mi1 neurons!
'Show' always clears the visualization panel before visualizing the neurons in the query!
Let's try using 'Show' again.
Done. Compare this with the 'Add' demo!
Try it yourself!

show_1.description: Clear the work space and visualize neurons according to a specific query.

script.message: Hi!
Let's query for Mi1 neurons!
'Add' visualizes the neurons in the query on top of what's in the visualization panel!
Let's try using adding some neurons.
Done
It is all yours now! Try it yourself!

add_1.description: In addition to what is currently displayed, visualize the neurons according to a specific query

script.message: Hi!
Let's query for Mi1!
Now let's add L2 neurons.
Now let's undo what we just did.
Now let's add L1 neurons.

script.query: Add L1 neuron in medulla column 0

script.message: Done
It is all yours now! Try it yourself!

undo_1.description: Go back to a previous step (UNDO).

script.message: Hi!
Let's query for neurons that arborize the center column of medulla!

Done

keep_1.description: Filter neurons in the current visualization panel based on a specific query.

script.message: Hi!
Let's query for neurons that arborize the center column of medull!
Now let's only remove the cholinergic neurons.
Done
It is all yours now! Try it yourself!

remove_1.description: Remove neurons from the current visualization panel based on a specific query.

script.message: Hi!
Let's query for neurons that arborize the center column of medull!
Now let's pin the cholinergic neurons.
Now let's unpin these neurons.
Done
It is all yours now! Try it yourself!

pinunpin_1.description: Pin (Persistently highlight) or Unpin neurons in the current visualization panel based on a specific query.

script.message: Hi!
Let's query for a type of Distall Medulla local neurons, Dm6, which are glutamatergic.
Let's add Proximal Medulla local neurons, Pm6, which are gabaergic.
Now let's hide the Dm6 neurons.
Now let's reveal Dm6, which are glutamatergic, that is in the visualization panel.
Done
It is all yours now! Try it yourself!

hide_1.description: Hide or reveal neurons in the current visualization panel based on a specific query.

script.message: Hi!
Let's query for Mi1!
Now let's color them red.
If only a color is specified, the last queried neurons will be colored.
Neurons to be colored can also be specified. For example, we can color GABAergic neurons blue, using the hex code for blue.
Done
It is all yours now! Try it yourself!

color_1.description: Color neurons in the current visualization panelvisualization panel based on a specific query

script.message: Hi!
Let's query for Mi1!
Now we clear the visualization panel.
Done
It is all yours now! Try it yourself!
The Neuropil menu accessible from the Header Bar lists all neuropils.
This menu can be used to control the neuropils displayed in the visualization panel.
First we hide all neuropils
Next we toggle a few neuropils
Finally we show all neuropils
Done! Try it yourself!
The Neurons/Synapses menu accessible from the Header Bar lists all neurons and synapses visualized in the visualization panel.
It is useful to highlight, hide, pin neurons of interest when the view in the visualization panel becomes cluttered.
First we visualize some neurons.
Now we open the Neurons/Synapses Menu and click on one of the neurons
This has the same effect of clicking on the neuron in the 3D visualization.
and brings up the info panel for this neuron.
We can hide the neuron
reveal the neuron
pin the neuron
unpin the neuron
and delete the neuron
Done! Try it yourself!

neuron_menu.description: Access the list of neurons and synapses in the visualization panel to highlight, retrieve info of, pin, hide and delete individual neurons.

script.message: The Cell Types Menu accessible from the Header Bar lists all cell types present in each Neuropil.
Most cells are only designated under one neuropil, hence some neuropils might not display any cell type.
This menu can also be helpful when exploring the dataset without prior knowledge about any cell type
Let's begin by navigating to the Cell Type Menu
and select AL(L) (right lobula)
Here we can see the cell types present in the left Antennal lobe related to the optic lobe.
We can select and load the first one, DNc01
Done! Try it yourself!

celltype_menu.description: Access the list of Cell Type that arborizes in each Neuropil

script.message: You can use your mouse to navigate through neurons in the visualization panel.
Let's first bring up Mi1 neurons!
To highlight a neuron, move mouse cursor onto the displayed neuron.
Let's try another neuron.
To obtain the detailed info about this neuron, single click on the neuron.
Info Panel on the left will display basic info of the neuron, and the synaptic partners of the neuron. Check out the 'Info Panel' demo for more information on how to use the Info Panel
Double-clicking a neuron pins the neuron.
Double-clicking it again to unpin.
Done! Try it yourself!

pin_select_highlight.description: Mouse operations in the visualization panel to highlight, retrieve info of, pin and delete individual neurons.

script.message: Here we show the function of the buttons on the top right.
Clicking on the button, the GUI Usage Info will pop out.
Now let's make a simple query
We can use the button zoom into the neurons visualized.
Let's take a screenshot of the visualization using the button .
We can reset the view to the original by clicking on button.
Now we will pin some of the neurons
We can hide everything but the pinned neurons using the button
and reveal everything in the visualization panel using the button
We can remove all neurons except the pinned neurons by the button
To remove pinned neurons but keep unpinned neurons, you will need to use the Neurons/Synapses Menu.
Done! Try it yourself!

gui_buttons.description: Function of the GUI button on the top right.

script.message: Let's explore some connectivity in the medulla
Let's add L1 to the scene
We then add some neuron that are postsynaptic to L1
Now let's open Graph View to see the neuronal graph with the button.
Now let's download the connectivity between these neurons by using the button
Done! Try it yourself!

connectivity_1.description: Explore the connectivity of visualized neurons with buttons

script.message: The settings menu can be accessed by clicking on icon on the top right
Browse through the setting to see what settings can be customized.
Done! Try it yourself!

visualization_settings.description: Open Visualization Settings to change background color, neuropil color, how neurons are rendered, etc.

script.message: A reference of supported English queries can be found by clicking on the button left to the search bar.
Done! Try it yourself!
Info Panel provides all information available of a neuron.
Simply click on the neuron in the visualization panel or from the Neurons/Synapses menu to bring up its information.
You can bring up one of pre- and post-synaptic partner by clicking on the + button in the list of partners.
You can bring up all of its pre- and post-synaptic partner according to the filtered value.
And remove them.
Since Mi1 has auto-synapses, it was removed as well. Let's add it back.
We can also add synapses. For example, let's add all postsynaptic sites of this neuron and color them white.
We then add all presynaptic sites of this neuron and color them yellow.
Done! Try it yourself!

infopanel.description: Bring up Info Panel for the neuron to access detail information about neurons and their synaptic partners, as well as key information such as NeuroTransmitters

script.message: A reference plot for unique medulla column index defined on hexagonal rings can be found by clicking
Done! Try it yourself!
Hi there!
A quick way to find neurons whose name contains a string is to use the $$ syntax.
The following query searches for all neurons whose name contains the string 'LPi21'.
Regular expression can be used with the syntax /rRE/r, where RE should be replaced by the regex string. The following query is the equivalent to the previous one:
Since LPi21 is a commonly known neuron type, one can also search for LPi21 with the following query
Try it yourself!

basic_query1.description: Query with string match, Regular Expression, and commonly known names of neuron types
basic_query1.category: Basic Rule-based English Queries (Specifying what you want to search for)

script.message: Hi there!
Let's show all Mi1 neurons that have arborizations in a medulla column, column 15_15.
We also support inputs and outputs queries, which is especially useful for filter neurons with known neuropil innervation and arborization.
Let's show distal medulla (dm) neurons that have input site from the first layer in medulla (m1) and has output sites in the a column 15_15.

script.query: show $Dm$ neurons that have inputs in medulla layer 1 and outputs in medulla column 15_15

script.message: Try it yourself!

basic_query2.description: Query neurons based on arborization patterns; supports 'in', 'inputs', 'outputs'. This allows for neuron arborization contraints such as 'with inputs in ... and with outputs in ...
basic_query2.category: Basic Rule-based English Queries (Specifying what you want to search for)

script.message: Hi there!
Let's display a T4a neuron
To add Mi1 neurons that are presynaptic to the neurons in the current workspace, and has at least 20 synapses from any one of these neurons, we use the following query.

script.query: add presynaptic Mi1 neurons with at least 20 synapses

script.message: Try it yourself!

basic_query3.description: Query neurons based on synaptic partners, supports both presyanaptic and postsynaptic relations
basic_query3.category: Basic Rule-based English Queries (Specifying what you want to search for)

script.message: Hi there!
Let's display two L1 neuron
Try it yourself!

basic_query4.description: Load a list of neurons using their Optic Lobe Body IDs using: show /:referenceId:[bodyId1, bodyId2, ...]
basic_query4.category: Basic Rule-based English Queries (Specifying what you want to search for)

script.message: This Optic Lobe dataset supports addressing layers/strata in the Medulla, Lobula and Lobula Plate.
For example, we can start by adding Dm neurons with inputs in medulla layer 1.

script.query: show $Dm$ neuron with outputs in m1

script.message: It is not recommended to query without specifying cell types or constrain with other information, due to the repetitive columnar structures of these three neuropils.

strata_layers.keyword: Building Circuits of neurons in Strata/Layers
strata_layers.description:
Building circuits by querying neurons in Medulla, Lobula and Lobula Plate based on strata.
In medulla, we have 'medulla layer 1' or 'medulla stratum 1' or 'm1', for layers 1 through 10
In lobula, we have layers lo1, lo2, lo3, lo4, lo5a, lo5b, lo6, and in lopula plate, lop1 through 4

script.message: This Optic Lobe dataset supports addressing columns in the Medulla, Lobula and Lobula Plate on a grid, referenced with a pair of indices (eg, column 15_15).
For example, we can start by adding L1 neuron in 15_15.

script.query: show L1 neuron in medulla column 15_15

script.message: As you can see the neuron is not unique, due to the way the grid is defined (not based on retinotopic columns). Nonetheless, you can add neruons from adjacent columns in the grid

script.query: add L1 neuron in med column 15_16

script.message: It is not recommended to query for all neurons in a column defined this way, due to the complex arborization patterns, this method of addressing columns might not be helpful as hundreds of neurons could have arborization in a column prodiving little intuition.
The same applies to other two neropils

columns_grid_pair_indices.keyword: Building Column Circuits with pair indices defined on a Grid
columns_grid_pair_indices.description: This dataset supports building circuits by querying neurons in Medulla, Lobula and Lobula Plate based on columns defined/addressed on a grid (strictly orthogonal in the medulla). Note that this is not retinotopically accurate within nor across neuropils, and a column defined as such would have more than one column-unique columar neurons such as L1. Syntax example: 'medulla column 15_15'

script.message: We have also explicitly defined the columns in the right Medulla with on hexagonal rings, referenced with a unique index. (see icon)
Let's begin with the column in the center of the medulla, column 0
We can build the first ring around the center column
This is slow. We can directly query for entire RINGs

script.query: color L1 in medulla ring 2 red

script.message: Checkout the full index map by clicking button.
Try it yourself!

columns_rings_unique_index.keyword: Building Column Circuits with unique index defined on Hexagonal Rings
columns_rings_unique_index.description:
We have added support for building circuits based on neurons in a column explicitly defined in the right Medulla with unique indexing on hexagonal Rings (as shown in ).
Both columns and rings can be called, .
This is only for columnar neurons that have a single instance in each medulla columns, including types C2, C3, L1, L2, l3, L5, Mi1, Mi4, Mi9, Tm1, Tm2, Tm9, and R7/8.
Syntax example: 'medulla column 0' or 'medulla column_0' (support syntax 'medulla/med/me ring/column_X' or without '_').

script.message: In this demo, we build circuits related to T4a neurons that sense front-to-back motion, in the center column of medulla (column 0).
we can anchor with Mi1, which is unique to columns queried by unique index shown in .
We can see that there are more than 1 unique T4a that are postsynaptic to a Mi1. This demonstrates that the motion circuit is not simply retinotopic. Let's keep a single T4a and trace upstream
We can see that there are more than 1 unique Mi1 for a given T4a as well. This will apply to the other columar neuron types in the ON motion channel

Now we have the LMC neurons that have input to the one white T4a neuron; however, due to local neuron types such as Dm, Pm, etc, the retinotopic connection of this T4a does not limit to these L1 neurons

motion.keyword: Builidng Motion Detection Circuit for T4a
